title: https://www.seat31b.com

last_post.content: 1/ A lot of people have been asking for an explainer on what is going on with Southwest Airlines and the massive meltdown that occurred. Hi, I'm TProphet. I write the Seat 31B travel blog (https://www.seat31b.com) and closely follow the airline industry. More importantly, I have a friend whom Southwest abandoned in Las Vegas until New Year's (along with his cat), and there was literally nothing I could do for him. Ready? Let's dive in.

title: They Called 911 for Help. Police and Prosecutors Used a New Junk Science to Decide They Were Liars.

last_post.content:
They Called 911 for Help. Police and Prosecutors Used a New Junk Science to Decide They Were Liars.
--
People who call 911 don’t know it, but detectives & prosecutors are listening in, ready to assign guilt based on the words they hear.

Some have been wrongfully accused & convicted of murder after someone misinterpreted their call for help, while those who used 911 call analysis against them face little or no consequences.

#Police #911 #FBI #Crime #CriminalJustice

https://www.propublica.org/article/911-call-analysis-fbi-police-courts

title: GitHub - hodgesmr/mastodon_digest: A Python script that aggregates recent popular posts from your Mastodon timeline

last_post.content:
I really like @mauforonda's beautiful¹ fork² of Mastodon Digest.³ A neat thing about the #mastodon API is you get the full HTML of a post. I'm rather 💩 at web UIs and my current implementation relies on fairly clunky iframe embeds.⁴ @benward recently contributed⁵ a better templating pattern, so I think there are some great opportunities for mainline improvements.

¹ https://mauforonda.github.io/mastodon_digest
² https://github.com/mauforonda/mastodon_digest
³ https://github.com/hodgesmr/mastodon_digest
⁴ https://mstdn.social/@feditips/107746558229070558
⁵ https://github.com/hodgesmr/mastodon_digest/pull/15

title: Stop Talking to Each Other and Start Buying Things: Three Decades of Survival in the Desert of Social Media

last_post.content:
Eugen Rochko says, "Mastodon will not turn into everything you hate about Twitter," but is this possible where so many have failed? Anyone hoping to finally see an end to this "cycle of corporate predation and enshittification" must read @catvalente 's brilliant primal scream:

Stop Talking to Each Other and Start Buying Things... >>> https://catvalente.substack.com/p/stop-talking-to-each-other-and-start

Followed by @pluralistic 's sympathetic:

What the fediverse (does/n't) solve (23 Dec 2022) >>> https://pluralistic.net/2022/12/23/semipermeable-membranes/#free-as-in-puppies

#twittermigration

title: Informal Government Coercion and The Problem of "Jawboning"

last_post.content: Regarding the Twitter files and, in particular, White House and FBI flagging content/users. When it rises to a 1A violation depends on whether the government used coercion. And what coercion is from a legal standpoint is not always clearcut, particularly due to a somewhat inconsistent line of cases that Genevieve Lakier nicely summarizes here. https://www.lawfareblog.com/informal-government-coercion-and-problem-jawboning

title: LAMBADA: Backward Chaining for Automated Reasoning in Natural Language

last_post.content:
We know from the long history of “classical” AI techniques tha ends-means reasoning (backward chaining) can be highly effective and more efficient than forward-reasoning.

This paper achieves significant gains on logic reasoning by inducing an LM to chain backwards from conclusion to premise: https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.13894

The LM is “wrapped” by a larger, ire traditional algorithm. This is notable because it acknowledges that LMs can be made mire powerful with external routines.

1/3

title: Tor Gets Major Backlash for Buying AI Art for Upcoming Novel From Bestselling Author

last_post.content:
Publisher, Tor, comes under fire for using AI generated art for the cover of an upcoming novel.

The cover designer paid shutterstock for a piece of art that was later determined to be AI generated. This image was then significantly edited (including correcting for AI generation mistakes like a person with a missing leg)

https://www.themarysue.com/tor-faces-major-backlash-for-purchasing-ai-art-for-upcoming-novel-from-bestselling-auth/

title: Three years on, the pandemic — and our response — have been jolting. Here's what even the experts didn't see coming

last_post.content: People who worked on pandemic preparedness anticipated the Great Toilet Paper Shortage of spring 2020. But many other things about the #Covid-19 pandemic have come as a surprise. I've chronicled some of them, with the help of a lot of people who worked on pandemic prep or who've studied coronaviruses. https://www.statnews.com/2022/12/27/covid19-pandemic-what-most-surprised-experts/

title: https://onlinecoursecollective.org/

last_post.content:
Inspired by a post from @hrheingold , I've spent a few weeks building https://onlinecoursecollective.org/, a site dedicated to sharing the work that my collective has done over the past three years.

The site is ready for the real world, and I welcome feedback and suggestions, and sharing.

I'll be adding more material from our discussions, and fleshing out the Resources page, over the next few weeks.

title: Not in a million years: It can take far less to crack a LastPass password | 1Password

last_post.content:
“As it happens we have estimated through a cracking competition that the cost of cracking passwords hashed with 100,000 rounds of PBKDF2-H256 is around six US dollars for every 2³² guesses […] Because of how powers of 2 work, the cost of making 2³³ guesses is would be 12 dollars, the cost of making 2³⁴ guesses would be 24 dollars. Ten billion guesses would cost about 100USD.” — @jpgoldberg

https://blog.1password.com/not-in-a-million-years/

title: Chickenpox and shingles virus lying dormant in your neurons can reactivate and increase your risk of stroke – new research identified a potential culprit

last_post.content:
Getting shingles increases your risk of having a stroke. Given that shingles itself has a whole raft of symptoms that are no fun, getting the shingles vaccine should be a no-brainer.

Yes, the vaccine can have miserable side effects. But having had shingles twice and also having a miserable time after my Shingrix jab, I can say with authority that wharever side effects you might get from the vaccine are nothing compared to getting shingles.

#shingles #stroke #Shingrix

https://theconversation.com/chickenpox-and-shingles-virus-lying-dormant-in-your-neurons-can-reactivate-and-increase-your-risk-of-stroke-new-research-identified-a-potential-culprit-194627

title: https://anonymous-animal.neocities.org

last_post.content:
the 2022 roundup;

April - Anonymous Animal (a 15 minute internet together-walk that runs every hour, on the hour) : https://anonymous-animal.neocities.org

July - ravel (a tool for making unfolding texts out of the details tag): https://ravel.neocities.org

September - World Ending Game (tabletop game to end a campaign in any system): https://everestpipkin.itch.io/world-ending-game

November - The Barnacle Goose Experiment (a body-horror abiogenesis idle clicker for the browser): https://everest-pipkin.com/barnacle-goose

The CSWEP article on economics seminar culture raised a couple of questions for me. Below is (my first) poll.

(See article on front page of this newsletter https://www.aeaweb.org/content/file?id=17929 H/t @paulgp )

Does your department have a policy of no questions in the first 5 or 10 minutes of a seminar?

title: Automated Story Generation as Question-Answering

last_post.content:
Our first attempt at backward-chaining with language models wrapped an LM in a recursive question-answering routine, where the algorithm attempted to guess what questions readers might have and preemptively answer them https://arxiv.org/abs/2112.03808

Anyway, I’m pretty excited about using LMs as part of a larger, structured process instead of just entering a prompt and generating continuations.

3/3

title: Add icon on media that lacks alt descriptions · Issue #1165 · hometown-fork/hometown

last_post.content:
Finally added a #Hometown feature I have wanted for a long time. Media in a timeline that lacks alt text now has a little warning icon in the lower left (shown here with mouseover text).

This is a quick signal to help people (like me) who do not boost media without alt text. It also makes images that don't have alt text... slightly uglier heheheh :AngelDevil:

https://github.com/hometown-fork/hometown/issues/1165

last_post.content:
"This digital feudalism is cloaked in the language of care and safety. The owners of these walled gardens insist that they are benevolent patriarchs who have built fortresses to defend us from external threats, but inevitably they are revealed as warlords who have built prisons to keep us from escaping from them"

By @pluralistic on this fantastic essay about #socialMedia and #walledGardens

title: Cards for Insight: Dialogue - John Kellden - Medium

last_post.content:
"I think one of the fundamental mistakes of the human race has been to say that when you have finished with a thought, it’s gone. But it hasn’t gone – it has “folded back” into the rest of consciousness. You don’t know it’s there any more, but it is still there; it may unfold again, or unfold in another form. So there’s a constant process of unfolding from the background of consciousness into the foreground, and then back again."
— David Bohm

https://johnkellden.medium.com/cards-for-insight-dialogue-c3fdbd53841e

title: The new space race could turn science fiction into reality

last_post.content: “while costs decreased and innovation in the reuse of materials and equipment increased, so did monopoly power. A handful of new space companies could piggyback on Nasa technologies that took decades to develop, while the established contractors which helped build them lost out. Taxpayers who funded the basic research got no stake in the wealth being created by billionaires in space, the largest public commons of all.” https://www.ft.com/content/a72ca87e-fe47-458a-a6ee-abb9c54254e9

title: Trends in History dissertations / statistics of distinguishing words as SQL

last_post.content: Here's a notebook using pure SQL (in @duckdb, on @observablehq) to see decade-by-decade trends in titles across all 50,000+ history dissertations in the US. "Transnational"/"empire" still gaining; "identity"/"modernity"/"gender" on the decline. https://observablehq.com/d/d3245f96271f48ab .
